block.p: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

Iraqis Say McCain's View Of Security Is Inaccurate After an American Congressional delegation led by Senator John McCain pointed to their visit to Baghdad's central market as evidence that the new security plan was working, the merchants there said they were incredulous about the Americans' conclusions. A1

Visits to Iraq have become a required part of the political wardrobe for lawmakers in the debate over the future of the war. They have brought up these visits, wielding their experiences to bolster their cases. According to the Pentagon, as of mid-March, 365 members of Congress had visited the country since May 2003. A12

Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, the most powerful Shiite cleric in Iraq, has rejected an American-backed proposal to allow thousands of former members of the Baath Party of Saddam Hussein to return to government service, an aide to the cleric said. A12
5 Peacekeepers Dead in Darfur Five African Union peacekeepers were killed in a rebel ambush in Darfur less than a mile from their base along Sudan's border with Chad, the African Union said. A8

No Trial for Britons, Iran Says Iran said that all 15 captured British naval personnel had confessed to intruding illegally into Iranian waters on March 23, when they were detained. But Ali Larijani, Iran's chief negotiator, said in a British television interview that ''there is no need for a trial'' -- a course Tehran had threatened. A13

Ukraine Parliament Disbanded A power-sharing deal in Ukraine collapsed when President Viktor A. Yushchenko ordered the dissolution of Parliament, the base of support for his rival, Prime Minister Viktor F. Yanukovich, whom the president accused of usurping power. A6
NATIONAL A14-19

E.P.A. Granted Authority To Control Gas Emissions The Supreme Court ruled that the Environmental Protection Agency had the authority to regulate heat-trapping gases in automobile emissions and could not sidestep its authority to regulate the gases that contribute to global climate change unless it can provide a scientific basis for its refusal.
A1

The Supreme Court declined to hear urgent appeals from two groups of detainees at Guant√°namo Bay who sought to challenge the new law stripping federal judges of the authority to hear challenges to the confinement of foreign citizens designated as enemy combatants.

Romney Raised $20 Million Mitt Romney's presidential campaign said that it raised $20 million in the first quarter, tapping two distant but rich networks -- Wall Street and the Mormon church -- to outpace his primary rivals.
A1

Debate on Felons' Right to Vote Gov. Charlie Crist of Florida said he hoped to persuade members of his state's cabinet this week to end the practice of stripping all convicted felons of their right to vote.

Chicago Police Chief Resigns Police Superintendent Philip J. Cline of Chicago resigned amid a public outcry over the lack of swift disciplinary action against several police officers accused of involvement in two videotaped beatings of residents in the last several months.
EDUCATION

Loan Company Pays Students Citibank, one of the largest providers of student loans, as well as five universities have agreed to pay $5.2 million to students and the New York State attorney general to resolve an investigation into their student loan practices, Andrew M. Cuomo, the attorney general, announced.
NEW YORK/REGION B1-5

Japanese-Americans Test Ruling in Muslim Case Three relatives of Japanese immigrants interned during World War II are urging a federal appeals court to overturn a Brooklyn judge's ruling, in a lawsuit brought by Muslim immigrants, that the government has wide latitude to detain noncitizens indefinitely on the basis of race, religion or national origin. B1

Manhattan Housing Prices Rise The prices and number of apartments selling in Manhattan rose in the first three months of this year, according to data released by several of the city's largest real estate brokerage firms. B1
SCIENCE TIMES F1-10

Drugs in the Waterways Residues of birth control pills, antidepressants, painkillers, shampoos and a host of other compounds are finding their way into the nation's waterways, placing public health and environmental officials in a regulatory quandary.
F1
Health & Fitness F7
SPORTSTUESDAY D1-8

Florida Repeats as Champion The Florida Gators, seen as one of the best teams in modern college basketball, defeated the Ohio State Buckeyes to become the first team to win consecutive national titles since Duke in 1991 and 1992.
D1
ARTS E1-8

Possible Pollock Paintings Sold The discovery of paintings thought to be by Jackson Pollock set off an uproar, and questions about their authenticity may begin reverberating in the art market, as the man who found the paintings has quietly sold some of them.
E1
BUSINESS DAY C1-12

Tribune to Go Private The Tribune Company, which owns The Los Angeles Times, The Chicago Tribune, The Baltimore Sun and other papers, announced that it had joined forces with Samuel Zell, a real estate tycoon, to take the company private.
A1

Chapter 11 for Home Lender New Century Financial Corporation, one of the nation's largest mortgage lenders to people with subprime credit during the recent housing boom, filed for Chapter 11 protection in bankruptcy court.
C1
